May I offer this one small observation? The determination (selection) of a
search technique might be based upon the possible information content
existing in the substrate.  This may be alluded to in lior-fainshil's post
below.  One can generate PDFs to make rough cut determinations re:
information or classification content.
 
If there is little or no apparent information content (platykurtic, or flat
distributions), a random search is plausible.
For mid-range distributions (mesokurtic), a novelty search may be
beneficial.
For leptokurtic distributions, directed searches seem to make more sense.
 
And speaking of sense, did that make any sense to anyone?
 
Ken Lloyd
 



  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
lior_fainshil
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2010 7:42 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Novelty Search


  

I will give an illustration for the difference between a random search and a
search directed by a random fitness function.
Imagine you have a hilly landscape and you want to plant a flag as high as
possible on the landscape.
A random search would be to airdrop a thousand people at uniformly random
locations and each person will plant a flag at the spot where he lands.
A search with a random fitness function would be to drop one person with a
thousand flags. This person will at each timestep choose a random direction,
walk a few steps and plant a flag.
In the first case you will get a representative sample of the landscape. In
the second you get a trail with the different flags being at similar
heights. He might land on the planes and miss the hills altogether. The
landscape will be poorly represented.
A more sophisticated search algorithm, will reduce the impact of this
problem, as the person will sometimes jump to faraway locations. The problem
however will never be eliminated, as a kind of a local search is in integral
part of any fitness directed search algorithm.

Additionally, I think there should be another subtler problem with random
fitness directed search, which will manifest itself in representations with
variable size genotypes. It will cause the code size to grow much faster
than what is optimally wanted in a random search and produce overly
convoluted solutions, where in reality we we want the solutions to be
simple.

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Ken"
<kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Probably the best way to quantify the difference would be to implement the
kind of random search that you are interested in and then compare it in the
same domain (and other domains, if you want to be thorough). Of course, if
you found that any type of completely random process consistently
outperforms fitness significantly in reasonable domains (as novelty does) it
would be a huge shock. 
> 
> You suggest that the random search that we implemented is worse than the
kind of random search that you describe. I could be wrong, but I don't think
there is an a priori reason to believe that any given totally uninformed
process is better than another. You note that our random search may be more
"uneven," which could be true, but there is no a priori reason to believe
that being "even" is better for a given domain. Generally, even with totally
random searches you are facing a kind of no free lunch situation.
> 
> Probably the most important question underlying your curiosity is why we
would expect novelty to be better than random. There are many answers to
this question, but perhaps one helpful insight is that novelty is an
informative gradient. That is, quite the opposite of random search, novelty
is information-rich, which means that the novelty metric tells us a lot
about how different points in the search space relate to each other. In
fact, one way to understand the relationship among random, fitness, and
novelty, is to realize that fitness actually provides less information than
novelty, putting it between random and novelty on the scale of
information-richness. The reason fitness provides less information is that
many behaviors that are different from each other receive the same fitness,
whereas novelty search would notice their difference. Thus, in fitness-based
search, moving among such conflated behaviors is similar to a random search,
because there is no gradient among them. 
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com,
"lior_fainshil" <lior_fainshil@> wrote:
> >
> > Looks like I missed that part. Sorry about that. If however I understand
correctly what you did, it is not exactly a random search. You write that
you run NEAT with randomly assigned fitness. In such search there should be
significant correlations between the tested individuals, since despite the
random selection, much of the genetic material is inherited from past
individuals. This is not at all what we would want in a random search.
Additionally you would get genomes becoming larger with time(probably much
faster than we would want in a random search).
> > I would expect these deviations from a random search to cause an uneven
exploration of the genotype space. Thus the resulting performance should be
worse than that of a random search. I don't know however if the difference
will be significant (It depends on the specifics of the evolutionary
algorithm).
> > 
> > I agree that it seems that novelty search will spend less time on
degenerate behaviors than a random search. Any ideas on how to quantify this
difference?
> >
>
